awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Integrated Research and Education to Improve Pavement Sustainability Using Bio-Binder
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to engineer sustainable alternatives to petroleum-based adhesives for use in construction and pavement.  The research objective of the project is to test the hypothesis that introducing bio-binder to asphalt binder can change the phase structure within asphalt binder to produce bio-modified binder (BMB) with desired rheological and surface characteristics.  Desired characteristics are an increase in BMB's adhesion strength and stress release rate, and a reduction of its viscosity at corresponding temperatures.  This in turn can improve pavement sustainability in several ways: 1) an increase in adhesion strength between binder and aggregate can reduce moisture damage in pavement, 2) an increase in binder's stress release rate can reduce low temperature cracking in pavement, and 3) a reduction in binder viscosity can facilitate use of reclaimed asphalt pavement and recycled asphalt shingles in paving mixtures.  It is hypothesized that when bio-binder is added to the asphalt binder, bio-binder molecules penetrate into the asphalt binder's matrix changing its chain conformation and molecular packing.  The interchain interactions between the long alkyl chains of the bio-binder and those of the asphalt molecules' side chains hinder the stacking of the aromatic cores of the asphalt molecules improving asphalt's properties.  Molecular dynamics simulations will be implemented to study how the two materials interact and how their interactions impact rheology, aging and adhesion characteristics of the bio-modified binder.  
This project opens a new paradigm in asphalt material characterization and modeling, enabling an integration of chemistry and mechanics while enhancing pavement sustainability and revolutionizing waste management practices for better environmental protection. It will offer a simultaneous approach to sequester carbon and address problems associated with manure management while improving pavement sustainability and enhancing U.S. economic competiveness by reducing dependence on petroleum resources.  The broader impact of the project will be further expanded by reaching audiences ranging from university educators to industry practitioners, farmers and K-12 deaf students to achieve educational goal of the project including 1) enhancing students' knowledge in the area of sustainable pavement and 2) providing professionals and decision makers with the scientific rationale underlying the use of bio-binder.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project led to the engineering of sustainable alternatives to petroleum-based adhesives for use in construction and manufacturing. The study results led to several publications and a book chapter related to the synthesis, characterization, and application of bio-binders from biomass. The study also led to two issued US patents (US Patent No. 11,155,696 and US Patent No. 9,637,615). All published work can be found under the Google Scholar account of the PI (Fini) and through her profile at Arizona State University; any unpublished data and analytical methods are available upon request by contacting the PI (Ellie Fini at efini@asu.edu). The research inquiry that was initiated in 2011 with the launch of this CAREER project has led to several lines of inquiry with local and international partners pertaining to the synthesis of other novel bio‑binders, multifunctional bio-agents, and compatibilizers for use in industry sectors other than construction.

One of the technological outcomes of the project specific to the construction industry is a bio-binder made from biowaste for use as a partial replacement for the asphalt binder used in pavement construction. Specific bio-binders were designed to have desired rheological and surface characteristics, including (but not limited to) increases in adhesion strength, flowability, and stress-release rate. Each of these increases led to improved sustainability: 1) An increase in adhesion strength between binder and aggregate can reduce moisture damage in pavement. 2) An increase in a binder's stress-release rate can reduce cracking in pavement. 3) An increase in flowability can allow for a reduction in the temperatures used for mixing and compaction, thereby reducing energy consumption while facilitating the use of reclaimed asphalt pavement and recycled asphalt shingles in paving mixtures.

In terms of contributions to the scientific community, the study outcomes led to an in-depth understanding of how bio-binder molecules interact with asphalt molecules to change the chain conformation and molecular packing of the asphalt molecules. Specifically, the role of amide-rich bio-binder molecules to reduce asphaltene pi-pi stacking and agglomeration was quantified and validated by both molecular modeling and laboratory experiments. It was shown that the long alkyl chains of the bio-binder and those of the asphalt molecules' side chains hinder the stacking of the aromatic cores of the asphalt molecules, reducing their agglomeration. The agglomeration of asphalt molecules is further promoted by oxidation as asphalt becomes aged during its service life, and this agglomeration has been implicated in premature cracking. Therefore, bio-binder’s reduction of agglomeration was found to be beneficial to mitigate the effect of aging while promoting the overall durability of asphalt. Another development was related to understanding the underlying working mechanism that imparts bio-binder’s strong resistance to moisture damage. Low resistance to water damage is a major concern in bituminous composites used in roads and roofs. Water damage is attributed to the desorption of molecules mainly due to water molecules having higher affinity for active sites of siliceous substrates than bitumen molecules do. A bio-binder made from the co-liquefaction of high-protein algae with high-lipid swine manure showed high resistance to desorption by water molecules, enhancing the resistance of bituminous composites to moisture damage. This was attributed to the molecular structures of the bio-binder having both lower polarizability and higher adsorption energy per unit area of siliceous surface. Additionally, bio-binder was shown to passivate the active sites of silica and replace water molecules over the silica surface via competitive adsorption with the water molecules on the hydroxylated silica surface. The latter discovery led the team to develop a biobased anti-moisture additive for special use in outdoor construction elements, adhesives, sealants, and plasters that are exposed to water.

The durability of binder is also defined by its resistance to solar radiation and heat; the results of the study showed bio-binder’s resistance was highly source dependent. The chemical composition of the bio-binder determines its resistance to aging and degradation when it is exposed to environmental stressors. Certain constituents of bio-binder were found to have a role as free-radical scavengers delaying the aging of asphalt modified by bio-binder, while the loss of volatile compounds from asphalt was found to promote aging.

In terms of societal and environment impacts, the study results offer a simultaneous approach to sequester carbon and address problems associated with biowaste while improving pavement sustainability and enhancing U.S. economic competitiveness by reducing dependence on petroleum resources. In addition to graduate students and post-docs, the project involved several undergrad students in project activities. The project also developed a training module on alternative binders for K-12 deaf students and organized annual hands‑on workshops for high-school students and middle-school deaf students.

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2021
Modified by: Elham Fini
